unit_learning_outcomes.description: Produce a technical report summarising key concepts, methodologies used, results acquired and their impact
Design, simulate, build, and perform hardware evaluation of circuits with one or more nonlinear components
Identify operational characteristics of typical power converters and electrical machines for a range of industrial applications
Explain the working principles of key nonlinear devices such as transistors and power semiconductors
Distinguish the main technical features of electrical and electronic technologies used in renewable energy and storage, electrical transportation, robotics and autonomous systems
Demonstrate fundamental knowledge in power computations in AC systems

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Self- and group-based learning to support project

enrolment_rules.description: (PHYS1520 or ENGG150) and (MATH1010 or MATH1015 or MATH135 or MATH132)

assessments.description: This is a major assessment of the unit. It will consist of 3 individual assessments and 1 team assessment, as follows: - Individual assessments: ◦ Oral presentation and demonstration of the project; ◦ Peer assessment regarding the actual contribution of each team member; ◦ Evaluation of project log book of each team member. - Team assessment: ◦ Project report to be submitted in iLearn by each team.

In each tutorial/ small group teaching activity session, there are several questions. A few example questions will be solved  in the scheduled session by the tutor. Students will be asked to solve the remaining questions with the help of online lecture material.  The problems will be designed to help students enhance theirs understanding of the topics covered in lectures and provide them with an opportunity to apply the knowledge they have learned from lectures to solve practical problems.  In the scheduled session, they will analyse the performance characteristics of various energy conversion and storage technologies. Criteria & Marking: (i) calculation accuracy; (ii) communications of assumptions; (iii) methodology; (iv) completeness.

The final exam will cover all of the course content.  This involves short answers and problem solving.  This is a hurdle exam and to receive a passing grade, the student must achieve at least 40% in the final exam and an aggregate mark of at least 50% overall.

relationships.academic_item_name: Fundamentals of Energy Conversion and Storage

data.description: This unit develops fundamental knowledge and skills in electrical and electronic technologies used in renewable energy and storage, electrical transportation, robotics and autonomous systems. The main goal is to understand the need of power conversion and signal flow in such applications. Prior knowledge and skills in physics and mathematics is assumed.
data.title: Electrical and Electronic Systems

description: This unit develops fundamental knowledge and skills in electrical and electronic technologies used in renewable energy and storage, electrical transportation, robotics and autonomous systems. The main goal is to understand the need of power conversion and signal flow in such applications. Prior knowledge and skills in physics and mathematics is assumed.
title: Electrical and Electronic Systems
